column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Mahiga (United Republic of Tanzania): My\r
#Text=delegation is pleased to participate in this open meeting\r
#Text=on the third anniversary of the adoption of the historic\r
#Text=Security Council resolution 1325 (2000), on women\r
#Text=and peace and security.
#Text=I should like to express my\r
#Text=delegation's appreciation to Under-Secretary-General\r
#Text=Jean-Marie Guehenno for his opening remarks, which\r
#Text=we found to be useful and very helpful in this debate.
#Text=Similarly, we greatly appreciate the presence of Ms.
#Text=Amy Smythe, Senior Gender Adviser of the United\r
#Text=Nations Organization Mission in the Democratic\r
#Text=Republic of the Congo.
#Text=The first-hand information that\r
#Text=she has provided about her experiences and about the\r
#Text=challenges in the field merits our careful and serious\r
#Text=consideration.
#Text=The demonstrated catalytic role of the\r
#Text=Office of the Special Adviser on Gender Issues and\r
#Text=Advancement of Women, under the leadership of Ms.
#Text=Angela King, is also highly appreciated, and we\r
#Text=encourage Ms.
#Text=King to persevere on that path.
#Text=The adoption of resolution 1325 (2000) was an\r
#Text=acknowledgement of the importance of the role of\r
#Text=women in conflict prevention and resolution and in\r
#Text=peace-building.
#Text=It was a further acknowledgement of\r
#Text=the fact that women not only are disproportionate\r
#Text=victims in conflicts but also assume a variety of roles\r
#Text=during and after conflict, including those of civilian\r
#Text=combatants, peace activists and participants in\r
#Text=reconstruction efforts.
#Text=It was also an acknowledgement\r
#Text=of the need to involve women fully in the maintenance\r
#Text=and promotion of peace and security and to make that\r
#Text=role concrete and visible.
#Text=Resolution 1325 (2000) prescribes a role for all\r
#Text=players.
#Text=Three years after its adoption, it is evident that\r
#Text=there is a gap between resolve and reality.
#Text=It is obvious\r
#Text=that, for resolution 1325 (2000) to become a reality,\r
#Text=Member States must take action commensurate with\r
#Text=operationalizing the provisions of the resolution.
#Text=That leads me to pose a few questions.
#Text=Have we\r
#Text=been able to give meaning to the resolution by\r
#Text=incorporating gender perspectives into all peacekeeping\r
#Text=operations?
#Text=Have we been able to allocate adequate\r
#Text=resources - including human resources- to permit\r
#Text=gender mainstreaming in peacekeeping operations?
#Text=Have we made any provisions for the required training\r
#Text=of staff, consistent with the resolution?
#Text=At this juncture, it is important for me to\r
#Text=acknowledge the appointment of an interim Gender\r
#Text=Adviser in the Department of Peacekeeping\r
#Text=Operations.
#Text=That is certainly a welcome development,\r
#Text=which, my delegation believes, signifies the relevance\r
#Text=and importance of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=While we\r
#Text=express the hope that the Gender Adviser will\r
#Text=champion the incorporation of gender perspectives into\r
#Text=peacekeeping operations, it is important to ensure that\r
#Text=her Office has the requisite support and cooperation\r
#Text=from the United Nations system as well as from\r
#Text=Member States.
#Text=We appreciate the fact that the position\r
#Text=of a Senior Gender Adviser is being earmarked for the\r
#Text=peacekeeping mission in Liberia.
#Text=We hope that that will\r
#Text=be standard practice in future.
#Text=I wish to avail myself of this opportunity to share\r
#Text=with the Council efforts that have been made in the\r
#Text=regions of East Africa and Southern Africa to give\r
#Text=meaning to resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=Conflict situations\r
#Text=have amply demonstrated women's abilities to take\r
#Text=active and leading roles in resolving conflicts.
#Text=Women\r
#Text=in the region are progressively taking a keen interest in\r
#Text=issues related to peace and security.
#Text=Political and\r
#Text=military establishments and armed groups are\r
#Text=increasingly becoming aware of the role and potential\r
#Text=of women in those areas.
#Text=Women, on their own, are\r
#Text=also increasingly becoming a powerful constituency in\r
#Text=advancing their role in peace and security issues and\r
#Text=have proved to be essential in that area.
#Text=The\r
#Text=involvement of women in the Burundi peace process is\r
#Text=a case in point.
#Text=In the broader context of gender mainstreaming,\r
#Text=we within the Southern African Development\r
#Text=Community (SADC), have set for ourselves the goal of\r
#Text=reaching a minimum target of 30 per cent\r
#Text=representation by women in politics and in decision-\r
#Text=making structures by 2005.
#Text=The overall regional\r
#Text=situation indicates that SADC member States are\r
#Text=making progress in that regard.
#Text=At least two member\r
#Text=States have provided for representation by women in\r
#Text=their respective constitutional amendments.
#Text=Women's\r
#Text=combat experiences and their civilian roles in the\r
#Text=liberation movements of many of these countries have\r
#Text=proved valuable and have paved the way for the logical\r
#Text=involvement of women in post-conflict governance,\r
#Text=reconciliation and nation-building.
#Text=There is a deliberate, gradual increase in the\r
#Text=proportion of representation by women in various\r
#Text=structures in most member States.
#Text=As most member\r
#Text=States in the region are expected to hold general\r
#Text=elections in 2004 and 2005, it is expected that they will\r
#Text=use the opportunities of those forthcoming elections\r
#Text=and other measures to advance and achieve the\r
#Text=immediate minimum target of 30 per cent.
#Text=The process\r
#Text=of women's empowerment will continue thereafter.
#Text=The\r
#Text=imperative is not to give token attention to women's\r
#Text=participation, but to acknowledge the fact that the\r
#Text=foundation for durable peace, development, good\r
#Text=governance, human rights and justice lies in women\r
#Text=playing a full part as equal partners in all peace\r
#Text=processes and in the maintenance of peace.
#Text=My country, Tanzania, is working closely with the\r
#Text=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for\r
#Text=Refugees to ensure the security of refugees, including\r
#Text=women and girls, as well as to ensure the humanitarian\r
#Text=and civilian nature of refugee camps and settlements.
#Text=As we in the Great Lakes region prepare for an\r
#Text=international conference on peace, security, democracy\r
#Text=and development in the Great Lakes region to be held\r
#Text=in June 2004, we are gratified to note that women have\r
#Text=carved out a niche for themselves as important\r
#Text=participants in the preparatory process leading to the\r
#Text=conference.
#Text=While we take note of the few positive steps\r
#Text=towards the implementation of Security Council\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000), it should be a matter of\r
#Text=concern to all of us that women still make up only a\r
#Text=small part of those who participate in peace and\r
#Text=security negotiations.
#Text=They continue to be marginalized\r
#Text=in most post-conflict planning.
#Text=My delegation believes\r
#Text=that resolution 1325 (2000) is a powerful instrument in\r
#Text=our hands.
#Text=Our challenge is to put that instrument to\r
#Text=work to achieve the results it is intended to accomplish.
#Text=That can happen only if we harness the political will to\r
#Text=allocate the necessary funding, to identify the requisite\r
#Text=staffing and to provide the training that is required to\r
#Text=make resolution 1325 (2000) a way of our political life.
#Text=Today's debate is a valuable contribution in sustaining\r
#Text=the momentum for change in that direction.
#Text=The trend\r
#Text=towards empowering women has generated its own\r
#Text=dynamic, which cannot be ignored or reversed.
